data.title: Obscure & Neglected Female Singers Of Jazz & Standards (1930s to 1960s)
data.meta_description:
The forum Search function is apparently on the blink, but I don't think this (neglected) lady has been mentioned yet on this thread?

[IMG]

Judy...
data.text:
Thank you for the question.

Torch Singers

I wish to say: Torch Singers are Jazz singers, whose performance is so emotional that they are burning as a torch.

But in reality everything is much prosaic: Torch singers are signers of torch songs.

According to Wiki, torch songs are simply sentimental love songs, where love affair effects relationship and one side moves on caring torch of love. So, in my understanding it not depends on music, but the lyric and could be within a Jazz, Pop or any other genre. You could say: "I have a big collection of great torch Pop standards."

Samplers of the torch songs

Claimed the first torch song ever written (1912) singing by Ella much later:

Torch song of 20's singing by Billie in 30's:

http://forums.stevehoffman.tv/threads/the-best-shm-sacds-part3.319827/page-51#post-16014394

Torch song of 40's written for Billie in 1941

Billie Holiday - Lover Man (Oh Where Can You Be) Decca Records 1944

One more torch song of 40's performed by Billie in 1946 for a first time:

Billie Holiday - I'll Look Around (Decca Records 1946)

Billie Holiday was and still is the best torch singer ever...

40's really stand out on a torch songs repertoire.

One of the best singer of 20th century:

Jo Stafford - 'Why Can't You Behave'

One of my favorite torch song of 40's (more on a blues side):

Belafonte Sings the Blues - One for my Baby

Nobody even came close to this version of this torch song of 50's:

Jo Stafford - You Belong To Me

Julie London's hit Cry Me a River happens to be a torch song of 50's:

Julie London - Cry Me A River (BEST version on YouTube).avi

Torch singers of 60's:

Brenda Lee

Brenda Lee - I'm Sorry

Dinah Washington (love her madly)

Dinah Washington / Since I Fell for You

Dinah Washington-Nobody Knows the Way I Feel This Morning

Etta James

Etta James ~ I'll Take Care of You

Aretha Franklin

Ain't No Way Aretha Franklin

I Never Loved A Man [The Way I Love You] [Stereo Version]

Janis Joplin was a "torchiest" singer of all not just by the nature of the material, but who literally burned out as a torch.

Move Over

Janis Joplin - To love somebody

Try

Janis Joplin- Try (just a little bit harder)

Cry Baby

Janis Joplin - Cry Baby

Piece of My Heart

Janis Joplin - Piece of my heart [HQ]

Maybe

Janis Joplin - Maybe (HQ)

We have actually talked about Ella Mae before. I'll search for the old posts, and will post them below, so that we can have a fuller picture of what has been said, so far.

I would agree with Mr. Jones that she is not obscure enough to merit extensive discussion in this particular thread. Ella Mae even has her own star in the Hollywood Walk of Fame. To this day, references to her as "the mother of rock 'n' roll" or "the first rock 'n' roll singer" still pop up here and there, too. Hence I wouldn't say that she has fallen into oblivion, either.

In any case, Ella Mae is great enough to deserve multiple mentions in this thread or any other one. So, I'm glad that 1940Zeffer brought this singer back to our attention. (Any further comments about her will be welcome. Since we have already covered so many of the really neglected singer, it shouldn't be a bit deal if we occasionally make comments about better known singers.)

Below: the older posts.

In agreement with the posts by Danby Delight and Stu02. It so happens that this topic came up for discussion earlier in the thread, too. It was brought up by Johnny B. Good, one of the thread's honorables residents (ha). As the OP, I thought the topic interesting enough to check it out in some detail. See our two posts, below. (To view bigger-size versions of the photos in my post, click on them, or go back to the original post, #575, on page 23.)

Yeah! And then, in 1985, Pathé Marconi and EMI Records went for a second serving:

We should also point out the existence of several CDs released in even more recent times (as late as the year 2015), including one on the distinguished Capitol Collectors Series, not to say anything of a Bear Family box, containing nearly all of her record output:

Re: previous comments about terminology ("neglected," "obscure"). We all clearly agree that these terms are relative. That's good. As is being discussed in another ongoing thread, even the likes of Dean Martin run some risk of becoming awfully neglected, as the decades go by! Still: for the purposes of this particular thread, we will continue to concentrate on classic pop and jazz female singers who did not achieve widespread & lasting recognition -- not, at least, when compared to the likes of, say, a Sarah Vaughan or a Julie London, or even an Ella Mae Morse. And on that note:

Flo Handy. You might have not heard of her but we could all successfully use her name to play the six-degrees-of-separation game. If you have been reading the last few pages of this thread, you do know Flo's more famous sister. And, if you are a jazz fan, you might be well acquainted with Handy's two husbands -- both of them arrangers and composers, the second also a saxophonist, the first a pianist. (No, I did not mean that she was a bigamist. And no again: the two men seen above were not her happy-go-lucky husbands. Let me take the opportunity to point out, though, that these two guitarists are her only musical accompaniment throughout the very good album that is being shown in the photo.)

Even after getting married to Al Cohn (and staying married to him for the rest of his lifetime), Ella Mae Morse's younger sister kept on using the last name of her first husband, George Handy. She herself was not only a singer but also a pianist and composer whose work was effusively praised by fellow musicians.

Maybe some of those folks were also in the know as to why Flo and Ella stopped speaking to one another for about the last 40 years of their lives, apparently going to their tombs without undertaking a reconciliation. (The Texas-born sisters were born between the mid-1920s and early 1930s. They died a few years apart, Flo in 1996, Ella Mae in 1999.) The origin of the feud remains a mystery -- at least to us, the general public.

Anyway, now we are talking about obscurity, on multiple counts -- the great LP, its worthwhile vocalist ... This is an album that has received consistently enthusiastic praise from the relatively few listeners who have heard it.

Smoky and Intimate is the only vocal work under Flo Handy's name -- aside from one or two singles on the same similarly obscure label, Carney Records. There is even a chance that the LP was not even commercially released, and that the extant copies are thus demonstration/promotional ones. The album finally became a little (just a little) less rare in 2008, when the Sinatra Society of Japan reissued it as a limited edition CD.

Other than on the Carney items, Flo's singing can be heard only in one or two orchestra albums, released on better-known record labels which nonetheless barely bothered to reveal her presence. (No credit to her on the front covers, nor in any other prominent location. To find out that she is in, you have to check the personnel listing on the back covers.)

Going back to the original Carney LP, Leonard Feather's notes on the back cover give us some details about how Flo started her public career in music, and as to why she did not become better known.

Her start: at 14 years old, Flo enrolled herself on a radio show called Which Is Which?, for which audiences had to guess if people in hiding (singing or talking behind a curtain) were impersonators, or the famous artists that the program was claimed them to be. Behind said curtain, Flo sang "Cow Cow Boogie," pretending to be her older sister Ella, and the audience was fooled. This experience was satisfactory enough to inspire her to find gigs as a singer when (a few years later) she had to go out and work for a living.

Critic Leonard Feather also quotes the vocalist's own assessment as to why such an "excellent and polished" singer did not become a well-known artist: Let's face it, I didn't try very hard. I sang for a while but I found I could make more money playing the piano, so I played the piano in funny little saloons in New York and New Jersey. In the decades that followed the making of this album, Flo and her husband's decision to live far away from the big-cities' entertainment scene would further contribute to her stay in relative obscurity.

Unfortunately, YouTube does not seem to have audio clips from the Smoky and Intimate album. There is, at least, a clip of a Carney single, though the selection on the single is a livelier interpretation -- nothing like what we hear in the album. All the same, it is a tasty morsel.

Okay, since you asked for it: I must ...

... I must commend you for coming up with a fine addition to the thread! Thanks also for a post that covers all the essentials about her.

Further biographical details of interest include the paradox that, despite playing the stereotypical dumb blonde, she is known to have been very intelligent, with a high IQ. And she not only sang and acted but also wrote lyrics, a batch of which she interpreted in Mulligan's company, and have been preserved.

I definitely hear the vocal similarities to Billie Holiday in some of her interpretations. When the occasion demanded it, she could also belt it out or get theatrical, in typical Broadway style. She was a good singer, most definitely.

On a personal note, I certainly like her as an actress but have long wished that I could like her more as a singer ... Her voice just doesn't appeal to me. Taste begin taste, there's not a whole lot that I can do about it. But that's okay, since she is not wanting for fans of her singing. (I know of lots of other listeners who are very enthusiastic.)

She made two full albums. The one with Mulligan is actually the lesser of the two. She is at her best in the other one, in which she adopts an appealingly smoky voice and goes through a very tasteful batch of "oh-I'm-so-forlorn" torch songs:

Most of the rest of her recorded output is from the movies, and available on soundtrack albums. The one with which I am most familiar:

From that movie, here she is, introducing a number that has become a standard, and which many famous singers have gone on to record:

My opinion would be that both qualify as obscure & neglected. I'd say that any female singer whose career did not go (or barely went) beyond the role of "big band canary" automatically qualifies! There were so many of them.

I appreciate that you provided one clip each for Carolyn and Virginia. When I listen to big band albums featuring unknown canaries, one thing that happens to me is that my attention span tends to be very short. To my ears, their voices blur too much with the music -- or, otherwise, do not measure up to the musical accompaniment. For that reason, I find that "piecemeal" listening of any such singers (i.e., just one clip per singer, and on the computer) helps me pay more attention. To my ears, their voices often blur too much with the music -- or, otherwise, the vocals do not measure up to the musical accompaniment.

In Carolyn Grey's voice, I do hear the same type of saucy attack that characterized a lot of Anita O'Day's big band work. Mind you, Anita wasn't the only one who sounded saucy back then. (Others, including the recently mentioned Ella Mae Morse, come to mind as well). Still, the fact that Carolyn was replacing Anita suggests that the style was being intentionally copied. (Not necessarily by Carolyn's choice. I believe that big band singers often had to acquiesce to demands from bandleaders and managers, who would ask them to imitate the vocalists they were replacing.) In any case, Carolyn has a pleasant voice; she sounds like she had the potential to become a fine solo singer. I'm reading that she did manage to do some post-big-band work in 1953 and 1954, for what presumably were tiny, short-living labels, one named Jig-Saw and the other Vito. (Below: Carolyn walking on Hollywood and Vine.)

Virginia Verrell also sounds pleasant, but, in the clip above, a bit too sweetly bland and old fashioned even for my personal preference. The NY Times obituary explains that she came from a vaudeville family of entertainers, which might explain my impression of an old fashioned, even slightly hammy vocal style. I am also reading that he was known primarily as a movie dubber, standing for Barbara Stanwyck during a screen rendition of "Ten Cents a Dance," and scoring a hit after performing "That Old Feeling" on film.

Thanks for introducing us to both singers, Mister Jones.
